Title: I was blown away by the response for my music including from Big B: Arya Dhayal
Content: ‚ÄúDrink some water, and hear this‚Ä¶ Amitabh Bachchan has shared your music video.‚ÄùWhen 24-year-old singer Arya Dhayal ‚Äôs father broke this news to her, the youngster from Kannur couldn‚Äôt believe her ears. ‚ÄúIt became the best day of my life, I was simply blown away,‚Äù says Arya, whose phone has been flooded with calls and texts since then, and her social media following has been spiking like never before.On Saturday, Amitabh Bachhan, who is undergoing treatment for Covid-19 in Mumbai, shared Arya‚Äôs video of her singing a fusion of Ed Sheeran‚Äôs Shape of You with Carnatic raag Shudh Dhanyasi‚Äôs swaras, plucking her ukulele‚Äôs strings. He wrote, ‚ÄúI do not know who this is but I can just say "girl you are a very special talent ... God bless you ... keep up the good work ... you have brightened my day in the Hospital like never before ... "!! Mixing Karnatak and Western pop is not an easy task ... but she has done it with such finesse and aplomb ‚Ä¶ there is no compromise on either style ... simply amazing!! (sic)"‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just been a month since I bought my ukulele,‚Äù says Arya, who stays in Bengaluru. ‚ÄúIn the past, I have tried to learn many instruments like violin and guitar, and failed. But ukulele just held on to my hands and I haven‚Äôt kept it down ever since. Singing with it has changed my life.‚ÄùArya, who first shot to fame in 2016 on social media for the recital of the controversial poem Sakhavu, has been winning a lot more of attention in the past few weeks from renowned musicians, ever since she began posting Western and Indian classical music videos on social media. ‚ÄúI have been learning Carnatic music for more than 20 years, but turned a lot more to it during the lockdown. I had just completed my post-graduation, and was staying in a paying guest centre. I had no space to play or practice, so every day, I used to go to my terrace at 5 pm, sing, and play for about two hours. That‚Äôs something that got me going,‚Äù she says.Interestingly, she has never received any training in Western music. ‚ÄúI have performed Western Music just once, in public. That was for a New Year celebration in Kannur a few years ago,‚Äù reveals Arya, whose latest viral video is a mix of a padam from Nalacharitham Day IV Kathakali and the song Believer by Imagine Dragons.The singer, whose social media followers include musicians Hariharan and Shahbaz Aman, confesses that her musical dream was never all about earning fans or followers. ‚ÄúI just wanted to share my ideas with those interested. And honestly, what I expected is criticism in return, as there were many cross-cultural elements in them. But the response has been encouraging,‚Äù says Arya, whose dream is to be an independent musician. ‚ÄúNot that I don‚Äôt like playback singing, but I love indie music more. I had released a song a year ago named Try My Self. I write and compose in English, and I hope to do a lot more of that.‚Äù

Title: Rishi puts the focus firmly on the need to conserve water
Content: Water, or rather the lack of it, is a major concern for most parts of Karnataka , especially Bengaluru. Highlighting this crisis and the need for better water management is actor Rishi , who has been posting a series of videos on social media about the subject. In a video chat with Bangalore Times, he explains his new initiative and more.Tell us more about the videos and the objective‚Ä¶Water is not a popular selling point. Look at how we have lost our green cover. India was a country with surplus water, which, over time, became just adequate, and now, we are facing water scarcity . Now, the situation is such that in many parts of the city, people get fresh water supply only three days in the week. Since Bengaluru is facing acute shortage of water, I feel it is the fundamental duty of every citizen to find a solution to it. Everyone needs to do something to conserve the water, but we lack awareness about how to do it. The idea behind the videos is to create awareness, so that even if not tomorrow, a few years from now, we can overcome the water deficit stage. It is the responsibility of everyone to contribute towards the conservation of water.Are you looking at taking it up with the authorities?I have been discussing with my friends at the Indian Institute of Science and Bengaluru Water Supply and Sewage Board (BWSSB) to understand the real scenario and trying my best to see what we can do to change the current scenario. I am now looking at doing a video featuring people who are working towards conserving water and taking that to the authorities to find solutions to manage water.What‚Äôs happening on the work front?Sakkala Kalavallabha is in post-production now. We were planning to schedule its release, but that will have to wait, considering that cinema halls are still shut. I was shooting for Ramanavatara when the lockdown happened and that will be the film that I will shoot for when I resume work. I don‚Äôt see that happening for a while, though, as actors work in close proximity of each other, increasing the risk of contracting the virus. I think it will take us another couple of months to seriously discuss resumption of shoots.What is your take on films premiering on OTT platforms People are watching films on OTT platforms. I think OTT is a blessing for smaller films, as they don‚Äôt get enough screen. Post Coronavirus, the number of films made will come down, allowing those that are made to stay in theatres for a longer duration. People will also expect a lot of quality in Kannada films as they are now used to watching content-driven films on OTT.

Title: Asif Ali‚Äôs Maheshum Marutiyum will have a car as its central character
Content: There‚Äôs something about Asif Ali and vehicles that spur nostalgia. While Vijay Superum Pournamiyum paid homage to the popular yesteryear scooter, his upcoming movie Maheshum Marutiyum will have the car occupying a larger space in the script.The upcoming film will be helmed by scriptwriter-turned-filmmaker Sethu , who previously directed Mammootty‚Äôs Oru Kuttanadan Blog. On the film that has Asif playing Mahesh, he says, ‚ÄúIn essence, it‚Äôs a triangular love story between Mahesh, a girl and a Maruti 800 . Mahesh‚Äôs father brings this car in 1983 to his remote hamlet that has limited transportation access and since then he has an emotional attachment to the vehicle and everything in his life is connected to it. In fact, decades later, it‚Äôs just the car and himself that has not changed in the village. But then a girl enters his life turning it topsy-turvy.‚ÄùAsk him why he chose the particular car and Sethu says, ‚ÄúMaruti 800 is a thing of nostalgia for a lot of people. It is also weaved into the socio-political fabric of Kerala because before the arrival of that car in 1983, we never had parking sheds for vehicles in our residences; it became a status symbol for us.‚ÄùSethu says that he was set to make his directorial debut in 2015 with Maheshum Marutiyum and had even approached a leading actor. But he decided to go ahead with Oru Kuttanadan Blog first. ‚ÄúYou rarely get to make your directorial debut with a megastar like Mammootty and I grabbed that opportunity with both hands. But I always wanted to do this film and all my friends including Sachy asked me why I didn't do this film? A prime reason why I have revived the film now is Maniyanpilla Raju chettan, who is equally excited about the project and is also backing the movie,‚Äù he explains.The team is currently busy with its pre-production. ‚ÄúThe composing for the film is in progress. We have also procured a car and its maintenance is being done now,‚Äù Sethu concludes.

Title: US-based Indian chef Sujan Sarkar feeds hundreds of Americans amid the pandemic
Content: He has impressed Leonardo Dicaprio, Sundar Pichai and Jude Law with his extraordinary culinary art. But in the past four months, Kalyani-born chef Sujan Sarkar, who works in Chicago, New York, San Francisco and Delhi, has turned his focus to feed hundreds of unemployed and elderly Americans who are badly hit by the coronavirus pandemic . Though restaurants have started welcoming guests in the US, primarily in alfresco areas, and workload has also gone up a bit, it did not deter Sujan and his team from cooking meals for those in need. ‚ÄúMy father, Jiban Sarkar, is an agriculturist and food is something I understand very closely,‚Äù said Sujan.Sujan‚Äôs mission started in March, around the same time when chef Vikas Khanna started his Feed India campaign. Sujan, along with his partner, Manish Mallik, decided to deliver food out of their three restaurant chains in Chicago, New York and San Francisco. ‚ÄúI was in Delhi for two months before the lockdown was implemented. I flew back to Chicago on March 10, just before the lockdown started in India and got stuck here. The situation is a bit better downtown, where I am living right now, but I can‚Äôt go back to my place in New York yet. The situation is still bad there,‚Äù he told us over the phone.Initially, they started to deliver food for the frontline workers ‚Äî doctors, medical staff and cops. ‚ÄúAs things got better, we started cooking meals for people in rundown areas, where the pandemic hit the businesses hard. We also offer food to elderly and unemployed people,‚Äù said the chef, adding, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt go out every day to distribute food packets. My partner, Manish does. We have our own supply chain and we maintain a strict hygiene routine. None of our staff members uses public transport. In fact, three of them live close by. Be it inside the kitchen or otherwise, we maintain social distance. Temperature is registered regularly and sanitisation work goes on all through the day. The hygiene standard is anyway very high here,‚Äù he said.Sujan‚Äôs team cooks around 300-600 meals per day. ‚ÄúWe work through an organisation and a lot of local community members come forward to help. Local farms send us fresh produce to serve the people. We cook everything fresh and never use any frozen item,‚Äù Sujan said. In the 700 grams of meal, they provide equal amounts of vegetables, starch and protein. ‚ÄúWe serve sauteed veggies, roast chicken and lightly buttered pulao. Sometimes, we try to add some desserts, kheer or carrot cake. That little something helps. The joy you see on their face is priceless,‚Äù Sujan confessed.The chef seemed to get a little carried away while elaborating his delivery experiences. ‚ÄúWhile delivering meals to police headquarters, the cops came forward to take selfies with us. In Englewood, the locals clapped and cheered when we gave them meal packets. These experiences can‚Äôt be described in words. I‚Äôve cooked meals for several celebrities. But this is an extraordinary experience,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúMy father and his team are working on dragon fruit cultivation in Bengal. I wish I could develop the same food supply chain in India, from my Delhi outlet. I hear, things are still not great there. Once we start our operations, we hope to do something there as well,‚Äù Sujan said optimistically.

Title: Is your body getting its daily dose of protein?
Content:
Vegetables and fruits provide protein

Our meals cannot provide sufficient protein

Protein supplements are required by those who gym or do an hour of exercise

Protein is required only to build muscles

Vegetarians cannot get adequate protein in their diet

Cheese ‚Äì 24.1gm (per 100 gm)

Paneer ‚Äì 18.3 gm

Chicken ‚Äì 25.9 gm

Peanut butter 25 gm

Soy ‚Äì 52 gm

The Protein Paradox study, conducted recently by a public health awareness initiative Right To Protein and research company Nielsen, surveyed over 2,000 mothers across 16 Indian cities, revealing that Indians consume inadequate levels of protein. The study shows that although 95% of the mothers surveyed claim to know protein as a macronutrient, only 3% understand the functions of protein or why one should consume it daily. Keeping this in mind, the Indian Dietetic Association has earmarked July 24-30 as ‚ÄòThe Protein Week‚Äô. Supported by the Protein Foods Nutrition Development Association of India, this initiative aims at raising awareness about muscle health and educate people about the importance of protein.‚ÄúProtein is not given the attention it needs and most people view it only as supplements. Also, eating out or ordering in and eating ultra-processed food and packaged foods, has affected protein availability in the diet,‚Äù says nutrition and wellness consultant Sheela Krishnaswamy.According to the study, over 70% of Indian mothers believed many common myths about protein, including it being difficult to digest and leading to weight gain. These myths have forced many to pick Vitamins and carbohydrates over protein for their families, including kids. ‚ÄúPeople need to understand that protein is a building block for the body, and it is a vital nutrient for growth, maintenance and repair of cells and tissues. It also helps to maintain immune health, which is required to fight infections,‚Äù says Sheela, adding that one needs to give the nutrient importance.‚ÄúVery few studies have been published recently that provide insights about the consumption patterns of this ‚Äòmajor building block‚Äô of our lives. Hence, it results in less protein in our food,‚Äù says nutrition expert Dr Jagmeet Madan, who is also the president of Indian Dietetic Association (IDA). So, what then is the adequate protein requirement for a person? This varies from one individual to the other, say experts. But on an average, about 1 gm of protein per kg body weight per day is required for adults. For children, a little more than 1 gm per kg body weight per day is needed for growth and other functions.According to the recent study, people incorrectly perceived that milk, fruits, curd, rice, buttermilk and chapatis were high in protein, while they were unaware that the following foods were a high source of protein...

Title: Is Taylor Swift singing about ex-boyfriend Joe Jonas in her new track?
Content:
View this post on Instagram

Most of the things I had planned this summer didn‚Äôt end up happening, but there is something I hadn‚Äôt planned on that DID happen. And that thing is my 8th studio album, folklore. Surprise ü§óTonight at midnight I‚Äôll be releasing my entire brand new album of songs I‚Äôve poured all of my whims, dreams, fears, and musings into. I wrote and recorded this music in isolation but got to collaborate with some musical heroes of mine; @aarondessner (who has co-written or produced 11 of the 16 songs), @boniver (who co-wrote and was kind enough to sing on one with me), William Bowery (who co-wrote two with me) and @jackantonoff (who is basically musical family at this point). Engineered by Laura Sisk and Jon Low, mixed by Serban Ghenea & Jon Low. The album photos were shot by the amazing @bethgarrabrant. Before this year I probably would‚Äôve overthought when to release this music at the ‚Äòperfect‚Äô time, but the times we‚Äôre living in keep reminding me that nothing is guaranteed. My gut is telling me that if you make something you love, you should just put it out into the world. That‚Äôs the side of uncertainty I can get on board with. Love you guys so much ‚ô•Ô∏è

Title: NHAI to beautify Ayodhya bypass for pilgrims & tourists
Content:
NEW DELHI: Statues of Hanuman, tiny flower gardens and fountains at regular intervals will be part of the major beautification of Ayodhya Bypass.

The National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) has approved Rs 55 crore for beautification and civil construction works for this 16 km bypass. While civil construction to upgrade the existing bypass has started at Rs 35 crore since March this year, NHAI will open the bids for beautification work on Wednesday.

‚ÄúIt was decided to divide two components with full government support. The progress of civil works is about 30%. The beautification work will start soon as the government is paying for it. The contractor can start work as soon it bags the project,‚Äù said an official.

The works were approved after Faizabad MP, Lallu Singh put the demand before highways minister Nitin Gadkari . ‚ÄúThe upgradation and beautification of the bypass will make the ride on this stretch fulfilling both for pilgrims who come here and for visitors as well. They will get a feel of reaching an important religious place. Several road projects have been approved and work has started around Ayodhya."

The bypass provides connectivity to Prayagraj, Varanasi and other parts of the country. Singh told TOI that the Centre has provided enough funds for road development in the area, which will boost religious tourism and economic development. The roads that are being developed include the Ram-Janki Marg and 84 Koshi Parikrama Marg in this region.

Officials said that plantation of exotic plants on the median will also be put as soon as cement concrete kerbs are constructed.

Title: Tulsi Kumar‚Äôs new single, Naam, is an ode to unconditional love
Content: Tulsi Kumar, who had lent her vocals to popular tracks like 'Tera Ban Jaunga' ( Kabir Singh ), 'O Saki Saki' ( Batla House ) and 'Enni Soni' ( Saaho ) in 2019, is now focusing on the independent music scene. This year, after working with Darshan Raval on 'Tere Naal', she has now collaborated with Punjabi singer Millind Gaba for the song ' Naam '. Presented by T-Series, written by Jaani and composed by Nirmaan, with music produced by Millind, the song is about how love always finds its way back despite all odds.A video was shot for it before the lockdown, which features Tulsi and Millind. Tulsi says, ‚ÄúWe shot this single 10 days before the lockdown. The video is about a girl who stands by the boy she loves, even after he loses his eyesight. I trained for the contemporary dance sequence that I had to perform in the video. I also attended classes and learnt to play the cello for this video. The cello is a grand instrument, and you have to know how to hold it.‚ÄùMillind Gaba shares, ‚ÄúWe started working on this song nine months ago and wanted the composition to do justice to Jaani‚Äôs beautiful lyrics.‚Äù Composer Nirmaan says, ‚ÄúWe kept the track simple and relatable.‚Äù Lyricist Jaani adds, ‚ÄúLove is a complex emotion, but the simplest way of explaining it is when people are there for each other no matter what the obstacles are, and that is what I am trying to convey with this song.‚ÄùTalking about the song, which releases today, Bhushan Kumar says, ‚Äú'Naam' is a song about unconditional love. The music video depicts a lot of depth, pain and hope through its beautiful storyline that‚Äôs sure to connect with the audience out there.‚Äù

Title: Ritvik Arora out of ‚ÄòYeh Rishtey Hain Pyaar Ke‚Äô
Content: While the production house says he is no longer a part of the show because of his unprofessional behaviour, the actor insists that he has not been able to resume the shoot owing to the COVID-19 situation. Read on...Two weeks ago, TV producer Rajan Shahi said in an interview that one of his lead actors was demanding an exorbitant fee hike and behaving unprofessionally in these times of COVID-19. Rajan refused to name the person and since then, there has been constant speculation about who the actor is, especially because currently, Rajan‚Äôs production house has three prime-time shows on air. All rumours have now been put to rest because we have got to know that the actor is Ritvik Arora , who plays Kunal Rajvansh in ‚Äò Yeh Rishtey Hain Pyaar Ke ‚Äô. When we spoke to Rajan, he confirmed the news. So, what went wrong between Ritvik and the production house?Rajan says, ‚ÄúA few weeks ago our supervising producer Vivek Jain called Ritvik. He said he could start shooting from July 1, but we should first speak to his father. That itself was unprofessional because he‚Äôs the actor, who has signed a contract with us. Yet, Vivek called his father, who asked for a raise in his remuneration, almost double of what he was being paid, and also a minimum 25-day work guarantee. What‚Äôs really wrong is the way he communicated it saying, ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt even think of calling back if you want to negotiate‚Äô. After this, Vivek reached out to Ritvik again, and even this time, he told us to speak to his father.‚ÄùRajan says he has always been open to discussion if anybody wants to relook at certain clauses in their contract. ‚ÄúSometimes an actor or a technician may have some concerns and want a change in certain clauses. These things happen, but they have to be discussed proactively. I have always been approachable. But for someone to say that don‚Äôt even think of calling if you want to negotiate... negotiate what? You are going against the contract! When they were asked to send an email on this, they started dilly-dallying. A few days later, Ritvik‚Äôs father started sending apology messages for laying down those conditions and tried to blame things on the COVID situation. However, we have a record of all communication exchanged.‚ÄùRajan adds, ‚ÄúWe have been very accommodating with actors who have genuine COVID concerns. If an actor wants to opt out of a show, we totally understand. But the behaviour of unprofessional people, who hold a production house to ransom, should be called out. In the case of Ritvik, there was a problem even last year when he didn‚Äôt turn up for shoot for a day and he was not reachable on phone, and we suffered losses. He apologised later in writing and we gave him another chance then.‚ÄùMeanwhile, the production house is in the process of shortlisting an actor to replace Ritvik. ‚ÄúNo matter how popular an actor maybe, it‚Äôs his work ethic and professionalism that is of paramount importance to me. If that is not there, I don‚Äôt mind replacing him,‚Äù says Rajan.According to Ritvik, COVID-19 is the main reason why he isn‚Äôt returning to Mumbai from Delhi. He says, ‚ÄúMy uncle passed away recently because of coronavirus, so obviously, everyone in my family is worried. Then we learnt about actor Parth Samthaan testing positive, which furtherfuelled their apprehensions.‚ÄùAsk him about his father‚Äôs demands for a pay hike, and he replies, ‚ÄúI first received a call from Rajan Sir in May, asking me when I would be able to resume the shoot. I informed him about my uncle passing away and said that I needed some time. I asked my father to take the communication ahead with the production house, as I was deeply affected by my uncle‚Äôs death. A few days later, Vivekji called me, and I told my father to talk to him and decide whether I should go to Mumbai to shoot. I am their only son and they were anxious because I would be living alone in Mumbai. I didn‚Äôt know about the conversation that transpired between my father and them. After I learnt about it, I told my father that he was wrong in asking for a pay hike. However, he didn‚Äôt ask them to double my money, he asked for a minor hike thinking that it would serve as a deterrent and they wouldn‚Äôt call me to Mumbai. My father was willing to send me to shoot from July 1, as he thought things would get better. He called them several times to clear the air, but our calls went unanswered. I asked him to apologise through messages and on mail. In his apology, my father stated that it wasn‚Äôt about the money, but about my safety and well-being. I totally understand their decision to not respond. However, I can vouch that my father wasn‚Äôt rude, nor did he tell them to not call him for negotiation. In fact, I received a mail from them on July 7 asking me when I would return. I didn‚Äôt want to commit to a date as I wasn‚Äôt sure if I would be able to stick to it, owing to the ongoing crisis. So, I wrote a mail stating that as of now, I don‚Äôt plan to return to Mumbai. There is absolutely no reason for me to leave the show because it‚Äôs such a good opportunity. This is a case of miscommunication and misunderstanding.‚ÄùAbout the incident that took place last year, when he went missing from the shoot for a day, he says, ‚ÄúBack then, there were issues from both sides. I don‚Äôt want to delve into it, because it‚Äôs in the past. In my submission, all I want to say is that if I was so unprofessional, they wouldn‚Äôt have retained me.‚Äù

Title: 30 Years of Keladi Kanmani: Raaja sir‚Äôs music gave life to the climax: Vasanth
Content: It was a film that not only marked the debut of a noteworthy filmmaker in Tamil cinema, but also one that showcased the actor inside one of our greatest singers ‚Äî SP Balasubrahmanyam . As Keladi Kanmani , which released on this day in 1990, turns 30, we speak to its director, Vasanth , who recalls the journey of the film, which started out as an offbeat project but ended up as a memorable blockbuster.Producer Vivek Chitra Sundaram had called up Vasanth, who was an associate director of K Balachander then, to his office and asked him if he could direct a film for his production house. "Maybe he thought that just like how he was making Pudhiya Paadhai with Bhagyaraj‚Äôs assistant Parthiban at that time, he should make one with KB sir‚Äôs assistant. I said I‚Äôd get back to him. When I told my family about his offer and my reaction, they scolded me, saying, I should be thankful that I‚Äôm getting a producer without me getting a story ready and approaching many producers to produce it. That was the surprise start of this film," begins Vasanth.The director says he had a clarity on what kind of films I wanted to make. "I like my mentor‚Äôs films like Aval oru Thodarkathai and Apoorva Ragangal. To me, the films that he did in that period, like Avargal, Manmadha Leelai, they are all classics. I like Mahendran sir for the realism in his films. And I like Mani Ratnam for his aesthetic sense, filmmaking technique and screenplay. I was also crazy about Balu Mahendra and Satyajit Ray. So, as an assistant director, I was influenced by all these directors. I wanted to do a film that was mature for my age. So, a romance between two mature people was the starting point," he says.Vasanth had worked with SPB in KB's Manadhil Urudhi Vendum, in which the singer played a cameo as a doctor. He was impressed by SPB's realistic acting style. "In my subconscious mind, I had this strong impression of him as a good actor, so we roped him in as an acting coup. SPB sir was a superstar then and he had sung thousands of songs even by then, but he was not an actor. So, I thought it would be a first to have him as a lead," he recalls.When he approached the singer, SPB told him, "If the film doesn‚Äôt do too well, I have my singing career to fall back on, but what will you do? Why do you want to take such a risk?" But Vasanth insisted that he act because he wanted his ARR (AR Ranganathan) to be a character, which would not be possible with a popular face.He says the film's producer, Sundaram, liked the idea of SPB playing a hero that he started the film immediately. Vasanth says he was in tears when he saw the double positive (which will have only the video and audio, and no re-recording or effects) and later presented him with a Maruti car.Vasanth's first choice for the female lead was Suhasini. "She was a wonderful actress and a friend of mine. Radikaa hadn‚Äôt worked with KB sir, but Suhasini had. But Suhasini was acting round-the-clock at that time, and couldn‚Äôt take up the film. My very next choice was Radikaa. She is one of my favourite actresses, and I think one of the greatest in Tamil cinema. She immediately accepted the film and did a fabulous job. She even got the Filmfare Award for her performance, though I feel that she deserved a National Award. She was so fantastic," praises the filmmaker.He says that he cannot forget the way Radikaa performed in the scene in which her parents die. "She requested me to give her 20 minutes to be ready for the shot. She discussed the scene with me for five minutes and went into a room and did not talk for some time; it was like she was doing some meditation. And then, she came out and broke down in front of the camera in a great way. It was a single shot, with many things happening in the background, and she was wonderful all that time," he gushes.Ramesh Arvind was cast because Vasanth worked with him when KB remade Sollathaan Ninaikiren as Sundara Swapnangal in Kannada, and they shared a great rapport.For Anju‚Äôs role, Sukanya was one of my early choices. She was about to be introduced by Bharathirajaa then, so she couldn‚Äôt take up this film. Vasanth also asked Ramya Krishnan, but she was busy with something. "Anju was more or less a new face, and many were apprehensive if she could pull off such a weighty role. But since I was a KB sir student, I had the audacity to take a risk. After speaking to her, I had the belief that she would do it," he says.Baby Neena had acted in Mani Ratnam‚Äôs Idhayathai Thirudathey in a small role, and Vasanth cast her as ARR's daughter. "She was a school kid and had exams at that time. And she‚Äôd fall asleep on the set during night shoots. But she had an extraordinary talent and was a natural performer. We vibed very well," he says.Other than Mannil Indha Kaadhal Indri, Ilaiyaraaja composed the rest of the songs in just half-an-hour, Vasanth informs. "The only thing he asked me repeatedly was if I would use the song Karpoora Mullai Ondru in bits in a few scenes. I told him yes, it would be like something that haunts the characters, and make audiences expect for the moment when we would play it in its entirety. Believe it or not, he composed the songs in the time that it would take to actually play all those songs. I did not have to ask for a second choice. Everything that he came up with was great to listen," he says.Vasanth recalls the special care that the maestro took for the re-recording of the film. "In those days, he used to finish the re-recording of a film in three days. For this film, he had completed two days of work, but the third day happened to be Pournami. And at that time, he used to go to Thiruvannamalai without fail on Pournami days. Only the climax reels were left, so my producer asked me to request Raaja sir to not go there this time and finish our film as we had fixed the release date. When I asked Raaja sir, he said, ‚ÄòWho told you that I‚Äôd finish this in a day?‚Äô. When I told him that he usually takes only three days for an entire film, and we had only two reels left, he remarked, ‚ÄòPoda! Those two reels make the film, and I have planned three days of re-recording for those two reels alone.‚Äô It was Raaja sir‚Äôs music that gave life to that climax," he praises.Mannil Indha Kaadhal Indri was not part of his initial plan, Vasanth says. "I felt that making SPB a singer would be an expected move. That is why he was an odd job man in the film. But at the same time, I wanted to show the character‚Äôs singing talent in a scene, and I kept thinking how I could do that. Suddenly this idea of breathless singing struck me during the shoot, and since SPB sir was there, I told him about this. He said it would be great, but laughed and askedhow I would finish the film, for it would be impossible for anyone to sing for five minutes without taking a breath. Though there is a misconception that he has sung the entire song without taking a breath, he actually sang that way for 40 seconds. When Raaja sir heard the idea, he liked it, but said that we should have it in the charanam and not in the pallavi because people could then sing the pallavi."

Title: Job drought in cities brings water and taps to Rajasthan villages
Content:
(This story is part of a series in association with Facebook.

Facebook

has no editorial role in this story.)

When work dried up in the big cities during the lockdown , many thousands of men from Rajasthan ‚Äôs Udaipur and Rajsamand districts trudged back home. Vijay Ram, a 28-year-old from Kuchauli panchayat in Rajsamand, says just thinking about the long journey gives him the shivers. He‚Äôs not going back ‚Äúat least this year.‚Äù And he has a good reason to stay home now.In the two months since they returned, Vijay Ram and others like him have changed the face of their villages. There‚Äôs piped water at last, long-neglected wells have been repaired, and agriculture has become more than a means of subsistence. ‚ÄúEarlier, we only grew grains, but this year we have sown vegetables also.‚ÄùTourists visiting Udaipur and Rajsamand take back memories of their rugged hills but life for the locals can be hard, especially in the tribal villages where water is scarce. That‚Äôs why up to 95% of men in some blocks migrate to Mumbai or Surat for work.Read more from this seriesThe workers who returned home because of the lockdown didn‚Äôt have to worry about rent anymore, but they still had to put bread on the table. ‚ÄúAt that time, it was hard to say what was worse, staying on in the city or returning home. We were out of work, money and hope in both places,‚Äù says 35-year-old Tola Ram from Udaipur‚Äôs Boramcha village.The returnees decided not to sit around and lament their fate. ‚ÄúWe began with efforts to arrange food and water in the village,‚Äù says Tola Ram. In Kanela, another village in Udaipur, they turned their attention to community works. The village didn‚Äôt have a water tank, so they made many phone calls to the collector‚Äôs office and the block development officer, says Ganesh Naal Gamethi, a resident.‚ÄúOur perseverance paid off when the village got its first 5,000-litre overhead tank. Then came the taps. Until recently, women fetched water from wells or used handpumps. The two taps installed in our village have made life a bit easier,‚Äù Gamethi says proudly.In other villages, the returnees are digging new wells, repairing old ones and raising crops with the new sources of water. ‚ÄúThis is a tribal belt where families have low access to resources like drinking water, sources of irrigation, etc,‚Äù says Saloni Mundra , knowledge and programme support executive at the NGO, Aajeevika Bureau, which is supporting the projects financially.The NGO‚Äôs help and the hard work put in by the people have transformed many villages in two months. Vijay Ram says they now use a pump to irrigate their fields. He expects a surplus that can be sold in the market. Putting bread on the table does not seem so hard anymore.

Title: Gurmeet Choudhary: Hard work pays, but audience mostly wants to watch star kids
Content: Staying at home for almost four months amid the COVID-19 pandemic, Gurmeet Choudhary found a way to stay positive. Meditation, he says, is keeping the Choudhary-Bonnerjee household sane. "Debina (wife Debina Bonnerjee ) and I used this time to interact with fans. We made a lot of videos about home workouts, the food we were having etc., and trying to motivate ourselves and others. But when a few people in my building tested positive for COVID-19, we got anxious. I was feeling low, and that's when Debina and I started meditating. Life badal di hamari mediation ne. It helped us deal with the situation and kept us sane and happy," he tells us.Commenting on the raging nepotism debate in Bollywood, the actor says it's a "natural" phenomenon present everywhere. "I am from a very small village in Bihar, I had no godfather but kuch bada karna chahta tha. After struggling for five years I got my first break in TV with ' Ramayan '. TV made me a star, but I wanted to be a movie star. So I started auditioning for films and during the initial days, I did face nepotism. But isn't it everywhere? It's natural ‚Äì a doctor will help his child if the child wants to be a doctor," Gurmeet says, adding, "If you notice, many star kids don't get signed after their first film flops. Yeh finally sab audience ke upar hai. Jab koi new talent launch hota hai toh usko bhi dekho yaar. But our audience mostly wants to watch star kids. Star woh hi banta hai jisko audience pyaar karti hai. Of course, hard work also pays, whatever I am today is because my audience appreciated my work."The virus situation in the country is disturbing, and Gurmeet says we have to understand this and be responsible. "One can't afford to be careless. My family is in Bihar ‚Äì my parents are senior citizens, my brother and sister-in-law just had a baby ‚Äì and our neighbours there recently contracted the virus. My brother is a doctor, and he is going to work everyday and staying separately. He isn't meeting his new born baby, yeh bahut badi baat hai," he says.

Title: Here comes Sorkalam, Tamil‚Äôs answer to Scrabble
Content:
Mother tongue as a sense of comfort

Like with most families, Scrabble is a staple board game at Chennai-based couple Santhanakrishnan R and Preetha Raghavan ‚Äôs household. Over the years, their pastime has often included playing the game with their daughter. One such round of the word game, however, ended up being an epiphany for them ‚Äî what if they could play the very game in Tamil ?This is the story behind their recent invention, Sorkalam, a Tamil word game. ‚ÄúMost of us have grown up with Scrabble, among other word games. Sorkalam struck me as an interesting idea because we often tend to play a lot of English word games, but not Tamil ones,‚Äù says Santhanakrishnan, a consultant in the field of artificial intelligence and data analysis.While Santhanakrishnan came up with the idea way back in 2016, he revisited it last October, to come up with a prototype, along with his wife. ‚ÄúFor this to work, we had to think of a few things like the number of tiles and distribution of points,‚Äù he says, adding that Thirukkural and vernacular magazines helped analyse how different word combinations worked. ‚ÄúWe then started working on a prototype with scissors, pen, paper and small cardboard pieces. We knew we were on to something,‚Äù Preetha explains.This was followed by a lot of trial and error before they zeroed in on the final product, she says, adding that figuring out a way to blend the uyir-mei-ezhuthukal on the board was the biggest challenge. Out of the total 165 tiles, 90 are wooden ones with Tamil letters, 55 are symbols/diacritics and the rest are blank tiles, which can be played as any letter or symbol.‚ÄúIn industrial design, we have a concept called design thinking, which involves a lot of improvisation. We made 20 sample boards and distributed them to people whom we did not know, to get genuine feedback. It was real fun developing the game as it was playing it,‚Äù notes Santhanakrishnan.The board game would have hit select stores by now if not for the pandemic, the couple says with a grin, adding that the game is now available online.While the lockdown has prompted many to give board games a try, the gaming culture should not be restricted to today‚Äôs times, they add. ‚ÄúBoard games are an important part of growing up for most kids, and for some, the love stays on for much of their adult life too. As for the lockdown, we wouldn't wish the game needs a crisis like the lockdown for its adoption. We wish the virus goes away, people get well, and happily play the game,‚Äù says Preetha.The game inevitably lets people explore numerous Tamil words in the process, the couple adds. ‚ÄúIn daily life, it takes time to think of Tamil words. This was the feedback we got from people who played the game. A few have even said that the game helped connect to their Tamil-speaking parents better,‚Äù Santhanakrishnan says.

Title: Amit Sadh warns netizens of a fake social media account pretending to be his digital team
Content: Besides trolls, actors often have to contend with fake accounts created in their name in the digital world. The same recently happened to actor Amit Sadh . On Saturday, the actor took to social media to warn netizens of the fake Twitter account @Team‚ÄîAmitSadh, which was created. The account holders were misguiding fans by claiming that it was managed by the actor‚Äôs team. Amit pointed out that he didn‚Äôt have anything to do with the account or wasn‚Äôt associated with it. The Bollywood actor, who is pretty active on social media, interacts with his fans and followers directly from his personal handle.‚ÄúHey u lovely people! There has been an overpouring of love from you all and I‚Äôm truly touched. But I request u all to not make accounts like @Team_AmitSadh as it misguides people. I want to clarify it‚Äôs not associated with me. I connect with my fans directly and will always!‚Äù the actor tweeted on Saturday, from his verified account.The actor, who made a mark in Bollywood with ' Kai Po Che ', has been part of films like 'Sarkar 3', 'Sultan' and ' Super 30 '. These days the actor is busy working on film projects as well as various web series.

Title: Narendra Modi: On Kargil Day, PM‚Äôs tough talk on ‚Äòdusht‚Äô Pakistan a hint to China?
Content: NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Sunday marked ‚ÄòKargil Day‚Äô by delivering his monthly radio address recalling India‚Äôs victory over Pakistan on the icy mountains 21 years ago but the messaging also appeared to be aimed at China.In his ‚ÄòMann ki Baat‚Äô monthly radio address, Modi recalled how the Army foiled Pakistan‚Äôs intrusion. But as he delineated the circumstances of Pakistan‚Äôs ‚Äúbetrayal‚Äù by attempting to stealthily grab land and to deflect attention from its internal troubles at a time when India was trying to improve relations, the similarity with China‚Äôs aggression along the Line of Actual Control (LAC) was striking, even though the PM did not mention China even once in his address.PM Modi, while quoting a Sanskrit shloka, termed Pakistan an incorrigible enemy who compulsively sought to harm everyone, even those who tried to help them, a description that seemed to apply to China as well. ‚ÄúTo the wicked, enmity with one and all for no reason comes naturally,‚Äù he said.He said people with such a disposition kept thinking of harming even their wellwishers. ‚ÄúSuch enmity will eventually prove costly for the ‚Äòdusht‚Äô itself, like Kargil did in the case of Pakistan,‚Äù the PM said, indicating a resolve to confront the border intrusion. Modi also made references to attacks by opponents back home as some have insisted that the government has downplayed the incursion.‚ÄúAt times, without paying heed to the essence, we encourage certain things on social media that are detrimental to the country. We keep forwarding things out of sheer curiosity. Despite knowing that it is wrong, we keep doing it. These days, battles are fought not just on borders, they are fought within the country too, on many fronts simultaneously,‚Äù he said.Modi quoted Atal Bihari Vajpayee ‚Äôs Red Fort speech in 1999 in which he had cited Gandhi‚Äôs mantra. ‚ÄúMahatma Gandhi‚Äôs mantra was ‚Äî in the face of any dilemma, in order to decide what to do or what not to do, one must think of the poorest and the most helpless person of India,‚Äù the PM quoted Vajpayee as saying.‚ÄúGoing beyond Gandhiji‚Äôs thought, Atalji had said that the Kargil war has given us another mantra, and the mantra was ‚Äî before taking any important decision, we should think whether our step, our endeavour, is befitting to the honour of the soldier who laid down his life in those remote mountains,‚Äù he added.

Title: Kolkata: Eden Gardens quarantine centre to start soon
Content: KOLKATA: The Eden Gardens is all set to house a police quarantine centre. Barely 15 days after the idea was conceived, several cots and fans have made their way inside after the necessary permissions were fast-paced by the Army. A gap of six feet has been kept between beds and a few bio-toilets are likely to be added. The Kolkata Police headquarters are planning to shift quarantined cops to this centre as early as next week.‚ÄúThe Dumurjala quarantine facility has 120-odd beds for our personnel. But we want to turn this into a 200-bed facility. Small buildings are proving inadequate to function as quarantine centres for the lack of doctors. Many are being forced to stay at home. This is increasing the risk of Covid spreading among family members . We cannot afford to keep quarantined cops at the barracks or homes,‚Äù an officer said.BCCI president Sourav Ganguly had on March 25 offered the stadium‚Äôs indoor facility and the players‚Äô dormitory to the state for use as a temporary medical centre. ‚ÄúWe will hand over the facility if the government asks us to,‚Äù Ganguly had said. Doctors attached with major city hospitals who are members of the CAB medical committee have offered to help with the quarantine facility.

Title: Covid hit tourism, MSME, aviation worst: RBI survey
Content: MUMBAI: Tourism and hospitality, construction, aviation , automobiles and MSME sectors are expected to be worst-affected by Covid-19, according to an RBI survey.The central bank conducted a systemic risk survey to capture the participants of experts on the major risks faced by the financial system, which is published in its financial stability report. The results point to the five sectors mentioned earlier, which are adversely affected by the pandemic.Incidentally, construction was doing badly even before the lockdown with over 24% of loans to this sector being classified as non-performing as on March 2020. This is second only to gems and jewellery where nearly 25% of the loans had already turned bad.Within the tourism sector, about 90% of the respondents said recovery within the sector in the next six months appear bleak. The aviation sector appears to be a close second, with about 85% categorising the future prospects as bleak. Bankers said aviation is most likely to require support as the sector is highly leveraged, has high fixed costs and is among the most affected.According to the survey, the effects of Covid are likely to remain for 3-5 years and may impact the quality of credit in the banks‚Äô books, the general risk-taking ability of entrepreneurs, investments in capital markets and real estate, and the saving pattern of households.In the survey, the categories that appeared in the ‚Äòvery high risk‚Äô categories include global growth, domestic growth, fiscal deficit. This is the first time that the survey has thrown up so many ‚Äòvery high-risk‚Äô categories, which is an indicator of the likeliness of the risk event happening. In the previous survey, no item was classified under this category.The number of ‚Äòhigh risk‚Äô items have doubled to 16. The new high-risk items include contagion risk following any other sovereign defaulting, the inability of corporates to raise foreign borrowings, risk that foreign portfolio investment and foreign direct investment may flatten. The domestic risks that are categorized as very high include slowing down of infrastructure spending, real estate price crash, rupee volatility, stock market volatility, liquidity risk and social unrest arising out of increasing inequality.In the financial sector, the existing stock of non-performing assets in the banking system and bankers‚Äô risk aversion remain big worries and impediments to economic growth. About 56% of the respondents opined that the prospects of Indian banking sector are going to deteriorate considerably in the next one year, as earnings of the banking industry may be negatively impacted due to slow recovery after the lockdown, lower net interest margins, elevated asset quality concerns and a possible increase in provisioning requirements.

Title: Viral Acharya warns against monetisation of deficit
Content:
Former RBI deputy governor Viral Acharya (File photo)

MUMBAI: Former RBI deputy governor Viral Acharya has cautioned against monetisation of the fiscal deficit , warning that it could trigger run-away inflation and external sector stress. Acharya‚Äôs warning comes at a time when there is a growing chorus for the government to provide an economic stimulus by borrowing money directly from the RBI.

Acharya‚Äôs criticism of deficit monetisation is part of his book ‚ÄòQuest for restoring financial stability in India‚Äô (published by Sage). ‚ÄúMonetisation of fiscal deficits by the central bank participating directly in the primary market for government debt or indirectly in the secondary market through its liquidity management operations would mean regressing to errors of the 1970s and the 1980s,‚Äù said Acharya. ‚ÄúThe constant refrain that given the lack of fiscal space, the central bank must accommodate that growth is a slippery slope,‚Äù Acharya said.

According to Acharya, for a sustained recovery, there is a need to clean up the financial system. ‚ÄúThe historical strategy of levering up yet another asset class to grow when prior leverage boom has gone bust and its mess not yet cleaned up has repeatedly failed, this strategy has repeatedly derailed the Indian economy‚Äôs long-term growth plans, unsurprisingly there is no asset class left to lever up and structural reforms are now critical,‚Äù he wrote.

In the book, Acharya has blamed the NBFC/real estate defaults to the glut of deposits that ended up with public sector banks following demonetisation. ‚ÄúBank deposit rates fell and savers searched for yield through liquid-debt mutual funds; these funds in turn sought a higher yield in the short-term commercial paper of non-bank and housing finance companies,‚Äù Acharya said.

Title: Covid-19 in Bihar: Over 80% of dental clinics closed
Content: PATNA: As Covid-19 continues wreaking havoc in the state, over 80% of the private dental and maxillofacial surgery clinics have been closed.In Patna alone, hardly 50 such clinics function for limited hours in urban areas and charge enhanced consultation fee. The situation in rural areas is worse as most dentists have shut their clinics.Indian Dental Association-Bihar president Dr Mohit Kumar told this newspaper that nearly 15 dentists, mostly from Muzaffarpur, had tested positive for coronavirus ‚ÄúMajority of the dentists in small towns and rural areas have pointed out that practices like thermal screening, pulse measurement, sanitization and fumigation as well as the use of PPE kits, masks and gloves will prove to be an additional burden that they cannot afford. Hence, the cost of consultation and treatment has been raised,‚Äù Dr Mohit said.Dr Kundan Singh, a periodontist with a clinic in Buddha Colony, claimed that many specialists had switched to the old hand-driven instruments for scaling and filling of teeth in order to minimize the emission of aerosol through a patient‚Äôs mouth and nose.The 35-odd dental clinics in the area between Jagdeopath and Saguna Mor in Patna are all closed. Dr Vaibhav Shandilya, a maxillofacial surgeon, said, ‚ÄúUnder the new normal, most of us are depending on telemedicine. Surgeries related to accidents, cancer or tumour, on the other hand, have been delayed.‚ÄùAt his New Dak Bungalow clinic, orthodontist Dr Neal Kedia has doubled the fee for dental treatment. ‚ÄúI have to make sure that there are disposable PPE kits and masks for the patients and the clinic is sanitized regularly,‚Äù he said.A Muzaffarpur-based dentist, Dr Harsh Singh, claimed that only 30 of the 150 clinics in the town were open for limited hours.Similarly in Gaya, almost 65 of the 70 dentists have shut their clinics. ‚ÄúThese include those falling under the containment zones with larger number of corona patients,‚Äù Dr Sakeb Khan Afridi said.Dr Vivek Vikas of Purnea also pointed out that there were 100 dental clinics, of which only 30 were functioning. The consultation charges had also been raised.In Gopalganj , only five clinics were open and the remaining 20 had been closed. A dentist, Dr Nishikant Shukla, said, ‚ÄúBoth patients as well as doctors are maintaining distance from each other.‚Äù

Title: RIL Future Retail Deal: Reliance inches closer to buying Future Group‚Äôs retail biz
Content: NEW DELHI/MUMBAI: Reliance Industries ( RIL ) is in late-stage talks to acquire the retail business of Future Group as it moves to bolster its brick-and-mortar play in Asia‚Äôs third-largest economy. The two have ironed out their differences over certain terms and conditions and a deal will be announced soon, said people familiar with the negotiations.Future‚Äôs interests are spread across various entities, including six listed companies. RIL will acquire the retail, supply-chain and related businesses of Future, which will mark the end of founder Kishore Biyani ‚Äôs play in India‚Äôs modern retail, an industry he pioneered. A point under discussion has been Biyani‚Äôs role after the deal. One of the people quoted earlier pointed out that companies in which RIL acquires a minority stake, the founder-promoters continue to manage the show, with the energy-to-telecom enterprise occupying board seats, and not otherwise.A second person said that the deal has taken time due to disagreements over the valuation of Future Retail , the flagship of Biyani‚Äôs enterprise. Future Retail, meantime, is facing increased liquidity pressure after it missed interest payments on its US dollar-denominated bonds last week. Subsequently, Fitch cut its credit ratings on the company. Promoters own 42% in Future Retail, which runs hypermarket chain Big Bazaar and neighbourhood grocery chain Easyday Club, but 75% of the holding is pledged as on June 30, 2020.‚ÄúThe board members of Future have finally agreed with the final contours of the deal that was being worked out among the parties. A resolution will be passed over the next few days,‚Äù said a person familiar with the development. Biyani is likely to retain the FMCG and residual businesses of Future, the person added. The deal will be financed through a mix of share-swap and cash.Emailed queries sent to RIL and Future didn‚Äôt elicit any response till the time of going to press. India‚Äôs No. 2 retailer by turnover, Future has been compelled to look for an acquirer after rising debt, falling valuation of its listed entities and a decline earnings due to the pandemic, started to weigh on it. The market value of its listed companies plummeted 74% to Rs 10,464 crore in one year and its debt has exceeded Rs 12,000 crore.The potential deal underlines RIL‚Äôs ambitions to dominate the Indian retail sector as it combines the online and offline formats. Once the transaction with Future is concluded, RIL will bring in global partners and investors in Reliance Retail , which, according to Morgan Stanley , is worth $29 billion.

Title: AIIMS-Delhi experts impart training to Bhojpur doctors
Content:
ARA: Senior doctors of AIIMS-New Delhi imparted training through a videoconference to the Bhojpur government doctors for Covid-19 treatment on Saturday.

Associate professor, department of medicine, AIIMS-New Delhi, Dr Neeraj Nishchal and other senior doctors imparted training to Bhojpur civil surgeon L P Jha and other government doctors of the sadar hospital, who have been assigned the job of treating Covid-19 positive patients.

Bhojpur DPRO incharge Rashmi Choudhary said the AIIMS-Delhi doctors explained the different parameters of treating mild, moderate and severe symptoms of the Covid-19 positive patients. The Bhojpur doctors were also told about bio-medical waste management for disposing of materials used by the Covid-19 positive patients.

Dr Nishchal and other doctors of AIIMS-Delhi explained how the doctors, the ANMs and other paramedical staff can keep themselves safe by wearing PPE kits while treating Covid patients.

Ara MP and Union minister R K Singh had held a videoconference with the Bhojpur DM, civil surgeon and other health officials of the district on July 24 regarding measures being taken to contain spread of the virus. During interactions, he observed that the doctors who have been assigned the job of treating the Covid patients need proper training. The minister then advised the doctors to attend an orientation programme with the AIIMS-New Delhi doctors. It was at the initiative of the minister that the Bhojpur doctors attended the orientation session on Saturday.

Title: 13% of TMBU research theses rejected on ground of plagiarism
Content:
BHAGALPUR: Nearly 13% of theses submitted for PhD by research scholars were found to have been plagiarized and were rejected by the Tilkamanjhi Bhagalpur University ( TMBU ).

As of now 39 research theses, which includes 23 of social sciences, 07 in humanities and 09 in science were found to have more than 35% of plagiarized content out of nearly 300 theses submitted since July 2018, when TMBU implemented steps to stop plagiarism for doctorate and other related degrees. Prof Equbal Ahmad, professor in-charge of university central library (UCC) and Anti-Plagiarism Centre (APC) confirmed that 39 PhD thesis were found having more than 35% of plagiarized content and have been rejected and the research scholars have been asked to make requisite changes.

The research board of TMBU, after a thorough discussion on the UGC rules, ratified and made an overall cap below 35% in making references of other published thesis or contents in any new research thesis. ‚ÄúIf the new research thesis is found to have more than 35% of plagiarized content, the research paper is rejected,‚Äù said TMBU officials.

It may be worth mentioning that the University Grants Commission (UGC) had formed rules regarding anti-plagiarism stating therein that researchers who are guilty of plagiarism could lose their registration and the researchers‚Äô guides stripped from their jobs.

‚ÄúThe UCC at TMBU has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Information of Library Content (INFLIBNET) to stop plagiarism,‚Äù said Prof Ahmad adding with the help of ‚ÄòURKUND‚Äô software provided by the INFLIBNET (Inter-University Centre of UGC at Gandhinagar, Gujrat), detection of plagiarism was possible.

Prof. Ahmad said URKUND is a fully-automatic machine learning text-recognition system made for detecting, preventing and handling plagiarism in all languages. Soft copies in the form of CDs of the thesis needs to be uploaded online for checking plagiarism through URKUND.

‚ÄúResearch scholars, who want to pursue PhD and other similar degrees have to take ‚ÄòNo Objection Certificate‚Äô (NOC) from the APC,‚Äù added Prof Ahmad.

TMBU VC (in-charge) Dr Ajoy Kumar Singh said the objective to enforce anti-plagiarism is to improve the quality of education and research in the universities and institutes of higher learning.

Title: Kargil Vijay Diwas celebrated at BRC
Content:
PATNA: The Kargil Vijay Diwas was celebrated without much fanfare amid Covid-19 pandemic at Bihar Regimental Centre at Danapur on Sunday.

A wreath-laying ceremony was organised at Veer Smriti where martyrs of the Kargil War were paid tributes by army officers of the BRC, JCOs and others.

A junior commissioned officer of 16 Bihar Regiment also laid wreath to remember those martyred in clash with China‚Äôs PLA troops at Galwan valley in Ladakh on June 15.

BRC officiating commandant Colonel Vineet Lohia, Lieutenant Colonel Sunil Kumar and Major Vaibhav Aggarwal were among the BRC officers present on the occasion. Officers from Jharkhand and Bihar sub-area of Indian Army were also present at Veer Smriti.

The Army personnel kept a two-minute silence to pay homage to those who attained martyrdom in the Kargil War 21 years ago.

This is for the first time that no civilian, ex-servicemen or their family members could attend the ceremony at BRC due to Covid-19 pandemic.

Meanwhile, the day was also celebrated at Patna frontier headquarters of Sashastra Seema Bal (SSB) at Karpuri Thakur Sadan in Patna. Frontier IG Sanjay Kumar laid wreath and paid homage to the martyrs.

Kumar and DIG Sudhir Verma also paid rich tributes to SSB assistant commandant Kishore Kunal, who sacrificed his life in an encounter with NDFB terrorists at Bongaigaon in Assam on July 26, 2010. Kunal‚Äôs parents and other family members were present on the occasion.

Title: No help around, man dies near ambulance
Content:
Kolkata: A 64-year-old man who was admitted to Bongaon subdivisional hospital with breathing trouble died on Saturday night while getting into an ambulance to shift to a Kolkata hospital. Nobody came forward to help fearing he had Covid and, after he died, the body was left unattended for several hours.

When he was referred to the city hospital, Madhab Narayan Dutta‚Äôs wife Alpana managed to help him down from the second floor of the Bongaon hospital and walked him to a waiting ambulance. However, he collapsed while getting into the vehicle. The incident prompted Bongaon Jiban Ratan Dhar subdivisional hospital authorities to initiate an inquiry into the alleged negligence of hospital staff.

‚ÄúMy husband suddenly collapsed, got injured and fell unconscious. I raised an alarm but nobody came to attend to him. Later, a doctor came and told me that my husband had died,‚Äù Alpana said.

Alpana‚Äôs brother Joydeb said, ‚ÄúHis body was lying unattended for hours on the premises.‚Äù

Later, a civic team from Bongaon municipality took the body to a crematorium.

Shankar Kumar Mahato, superintendent of Bongaon hospital said, ‚ÄúWe have received a complaint and are looking into the matter seriously. If some hospital staffers are found guilty of negligence, stern action will be taken against them.‚Äù

Title: Proposed isolation centre for doctors hits a roadblock
Content:
GAYA: The proposed isolation centre exclusively for doctors in the IMA Bhavan, has hit a road block as paramedics are not available to help manage the centre. According to Gaya IMA President Dr Ram Sewak Prasad Singh, though several IMA members have volunteered to run the centre for doctors, paramedical staff is not available. ‚ÄúThe proposal virtually stands shelved,‚Äù said the IMA chief.

Meanwhile, as per stories doing the rounds, the compounder of a Covid positive Gaya doctor refused to administer injection to his boss. More than a dozen of Gaya doctors have so far tested positive. Dr Ashwini Nanadkuliar, a private medical practitioner of the town was the first in the state to die of Covid-19. Two more doctors have been referred to AIIMS, Patna.

The offer officially made to the NGOs to come forward and run isolation centres too has not found any takers. According to Suresh Kumar, executive director of Centre Direct, a Patna-based NGO that has been active in Gaya as well, the NGOs do not have the skilled manpower required to run specialist facilities like isolation centres.

Title: Covid claims lives of two more cops
Content: PATNA: A 2009-batch police sub-inspector (SI), who was tested positive for Covid-19 ten days back, died at Anugrah Narayan Magadh Medical College and Hospital (ANMMCH) in Gaya on Sunday. The SI was identified as Gajendra Singh (38). He was posted at Town police station of Jehanabad district. The dead cop was a resident of Shivbhajan Bigha in Aurangabad.‚ÄúGajendra was admitted to ANMMCH for treatment. We received information about his death on Sunday,‚Äù Jehanabad SP Maneesh saidMeanwhile, an assistant sub-inspector, B K Tiwary (55), who was posted at Amarpur police station in Banka district, was tested positive for Covid-19 on Sunday after his death. The ASI, a native of Deoria in Uttar Pradesh, had died in his official quarter at Amarpur around 4pm on Saturday.SHO of Amarpur police station Kumar Sunny said they had rushed Tiwary to a referral hospital at Amarpur where doctors declared him brought dead. ‚ÄúHis wife called us around 4pm to say that he was not responding,‚Äù the SHO said, adding the ASI was suffering from severe cough and other ailments.‚ÄúA sub-inspector and three constables at Amarpur police station were also tested Covid-19 positive on Sunday,‚Äù he said.

Title: PWD-run auditorium to turn safe home
Content:
Kolkata: Uttirna, the state PWD-run auditorium in Alipore, is set to become a safe house. After chief minister Mamata Banerjee asked state urban development minister Firhad Hakim to explore the opportunity of turning the signature auditorium into a safe home for Covid patients, Hakim, on Sunday, visited the site and took stock of the facilities there.

According to sources, the safe house may become a 500-bed facility. ‚ÄúThere is a lot of space inside the complex,‚Äù a PWD official said.

Hakim, also the chairman of the board of administrators in the KMC, recently visited a number of state- and private-owned properties to see if they could be converted into safe houses. State home secretary Alapan Bandopadhyay, who is a nodal officer for overseeing anti-Covid operations, had asked KMC to look for safe houses.

The buildings likely to become safe houses include Geetanjali stadium, Santoshpur stadium and a high-rise off EM Bypass. ‚ÄúWe are searching for more such safe houses for elderly citizens who are Covid-suspects but can‚Äôt get home quarantined for want of space,‚Äù said a KMC official.

Title: Here's what cheating dreams can actually mean
Content: Not everybody dreams of cheating or being cheated on. If your relationship is solid with your significant other, you probably won't dream of cheating on your partner. And so, if you ever get dreams where either you are cheating or being cheated upon, do not run straight to your partner giving out every single detail. You dreaming about cheating doesn't necessarily mean you are looking for a sidepiece. In fact, having a cheating dream can actually mean almost anything. Even in dreams where you see your partner playing you, depends on your past experiences.It could mean you are feeling guilty about something in your real life. Guilt or concern about something you are doing can be the main reason for you to see such dreams.It could also mean that your current relationship is missing something that you need. If you feel that excitement and passion are missing in your relationship, you might go on dreaming about it with someone else.Another big reason could also be because you might have a harmless crush on someone else. This could also lead to cheating dreams.It could mean that there's a third wheel in your relationship that's affecting you in unknown ways. You aren't particularly jealous or insecure in real, but the thought of your partner spending time or being close friends with someone else might affect you deeply and result in such dreams.Another major reason could be because you don't trust your partner. Maybe you caught them red-handed flirting with someone else or that they don't take interest in you anymore or simply want to spend time without you. This could result in trusting issues which ultimately makes you dream of your partner cheating on you.Dreams, where you're being cheated on, could also mean you are very insecure about your relationship in real life. Maybe you aren't feeling good about yourself or you feel you aren't enough for your partner and that they might go around wanting to meet their needs with someone else.

Title: Job insecurity takes toll on many professionals
Content: PATNA: As work from home has become the new normal amid Covid-19 pandemic, several working professionals are going through insomnia, restlessness, anxiety, boredom and backaches.Several private offices have not opened since nationwide lockdown was announced in the last week of March. Roshni Gupta, who works for a US- based educational firm, said she spent most days sitting in front of computer or on her cellphone. ‚ÄúThe workload has increased due to several challenges we face like disturbance at home and poor connectivity. There is no fixed working time,‚Äù she said.Vikash Kumar, a resident of Bhootnath Road and employee of an automobile company, said job insecurity was very difficult to deal with. ‚ÄúThe company has already reduced our salary by 30% and fired some employees,‚Äù he said.Like Vikash, Neeraj Sinha also complained of frustration, anxiety and restlessness. ‚ÄúI started losing sleep mainly due to office messages which pop up on my cellphone throughout the day. The restlessness is taking toll on my work performance,‚Äù he said.Shweta Singh, who works for a development agency, said, ‚ÄúI always run out of creative ideas due to lack of proper working environment. The virtual work culture is not an easy task.‚ÄùCity-based psychologist Dr Binda Singh said job insecurity, work pressure, rising cases of coronavirus and conflicts in the family often put working professionals under stress, leading to psychosomatic disorders like abdominal pain, headache, constipation and nausea.‚ÄúSuch cases have increased manifold as people are more frustrated due to negative thoughts, which harm them physically and emotionally. Because of high stress level, people often show their anger to family members,‚Äù she said.Stressing on the need to remain calm during the pandemic, Dr Binda said the acceptance of the circumstance was the only option. ‚ÄúIt is the time when people need to remain calm and create positive environment at home through time management, proper diet, adequate sleep, exercise, deep breathing and music,‚Äù she saidMany who have lost job are going for counselling. ‚ÄúIt is difficult to find a new job under the present circumstances. I have started taking online counselling classes after returning from Noida,‚Äù said a resident of Danapur, who recently lost his job.

Title: Admin cracks whip on officials,alters strategy to combat Covid
Content: Varanasi: Facing intense pressure due to the sharp rise in Covid-19 cases in Varanasi in past one week, officials intensified the process of streamlining arrangements to combat the crisis.Senior officials are rethinking strategies for combating the pandemic while they also initiated strict action against those found lax in their work.Divisional commissioner Deepak Agrawal convened a meeting of all senior officials of district administration, police, health and other department on Friday evening.Implementing strict norms, Agrawal fixed the time limit for hospitalisation of those testing positive as well as for deciding whether they can be put in home isolation.Taking serious note of laxities, Agrawal directed the CMO and his team to stay at Covid-19 integrated control command centre and decide whether a patient has to be hospitalised or stay in home isolation within 24 hours after arrival of report.He asked directed them to keep ready ambulances to ferry patients to health facilities if they require hospitalisation.In past five days, around Covid-19 cases are being detected per day while complaints have been pouring about delay in hospitalisation of patients after arrival of lab report and improper arrangements at L-1 and L-2 hospitals.District magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma also sought explanation from additional CMO Dr S S Kanojia for laxities in Integrated Data Surveillance Project (IDSP) as well as other officials of health and regional transport departments.All government and private laboratories have been asked to record proper details of persons giving samples for ease in contacting them on arrival of their report. Health officials were asked to coordinate with Varanasi Municipal Corporation‚Äôs Bhelupur zonal officer for cremation of bodies as per Covid protocol. He also ordered 100% sampling of people found having cold, cough and breathing problem during screening drive between July 5 and 15.All primary and community health centre in-charges will be nodal officers for Covid-19 related work at their centres.The DM said minimum 70 samples should be collected at urban and 100 samples in rural centre per day. If any centre shows zero sample, the day‚Äôs salary of its in-charge will be deducted, he added.ReplyReply allForward

Title: Discounts, offers by 2-wheeler companies make a disappearing act this monsoon
Content:
Chennai: Discounts and incentive schemes have disappeared from the motorcycle and scooter market even though July-August monsoon months ‚Äî Shradh or Aadi ‚Äî are the weakest marketing periods for two wheeler sales.

Under a normal circumstances, company and dealer schemes as well as discounts during this season leading up to Shradh in the north vary from around 7%-10% of vehicle price. But this year, lockdown losses and a demand that‚Äôs higher than supply have meant neither companies nor dealerships are offering any discount. ‚ÄúRight now no company or dealership is offering any discounts or benefits except may be in some niche geographies,‚Äù said Nikunj Sanghi who runs Hero Motocorp dealership JS Fourwheel Motors in Alwar. Normally, Q2 is the weakest quarter for two wheeler sales due to the monsoon and shradh and companies use this time to build inventory for the festive season. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why discount/benefit offers ranging between Rs 1,500-Rs 3,000 is normal during this monsoon season,‚Äù added Sanghi. This year however the discounts have vanished. Several reasons have contributed to this. ‚ÄúBecause of BS6 transition inventory pipelines were empty when the lockdown happened,‚Äù said Sanghi. ‚ÄúNow two wheeler companies are taking time to ramp up production and the supply constraint is a bigger challenge than demand which is boosted both by rural pull and the pent-up demand.‚Äù

Also dealers have suffered heavy losses during the 45-60 day zero sales period so ‚Äúthey cannot afford to pay any discounts,‚Äù he said.

Financiers say so far June-July hasn‚Äôt been a washout. ‚ÄúJune sales of two wheelers were good and loan disbursements were also good. I am told July isn‚Äôt as good as June,‚Äù said YS Chakravarthy, MD, Shriram City Union Finance, India‚Äôs largest two wheeler financier by volume.

Dealers however say the percentage of financed vehicles and the percentage of financing have both fallen with banks and NBFCs turning cautious. ‚ÄúEarlier 90% of on-road price could be financed but now it is 75% and financiers are also cautious so the cash sales have been going up particularly in semi urban and rural markets,‚Äù said a FADA official.

Title: Kunwar Pal Banjara, accused in Rewa royal museum robbery, arrested
Content:
Kanpur: The Kannauj police on Sundy arrested a wanted dacoit who had jumped bail two years ago in a case of huge robbery at the royal museum in Rewa, Madhya Pradesh in 2012, in which he and his 20 aides had taken away antiques and jewellery worth Rs 50 crore.

The accused identified as Kunwar Pal Banjara , resident of Ram Nagar under Thatia police station of Kannauj, was arrested in the small hours of Sunday, said Kannauj SP Amrendra Prasad Singh.

Banjara had allegedly murdered a security guard of the Rewa royal museum in 2012, and was arrested five years later in 2017. He was then released on bail in 2018, but he jumped the bail.

‚ÄúHe kept shifting his location to evade arrest. The court had then issued a non-bailable warrant against him and he was declared a ‚Äòproclaimed offender‚Äô,‚Äù said the SP.

As per police, they had received a tip-off about his arrival in Kannauj. They kept track of Banjara and arrested him on late Saturday night.

Police said Banjara, against whom 27 criminal cases remain pending, is also in the list of top ten criminals of the district.

The robbery at the royal museum had occurred on October 18, 2012. Banjara and his gang had targeted the museum in Rewa fort after killing the guard Kamla Prasad, and had escaped with several antiques.

SP Kannauj said the antiques dated back to 500 years.

‚ÄúBanjara and his aides had decamped with a pen pistol of year 1911 which was purchased by Raja Gulab Singh, a 40 kg silver chattri (umbrella), six antique swords, a silver ornamented hukkah, ornamental dresses and fabrics used to deck up elephants on special occasions, two antique pistols, silver and gold wedding dresses, one gold and three silver lamps,‚Äù said police.

A country-made pistol of .315 bore and several live catridges were seized from his possession on Sunday.

Title: Youth lynched on theft suspicion in Jehanabad
Content:
PATNA: A 24-year-old youth, Lalbabu Yadav, was lynched by a mob on suspicion of being a thief at Chunukpur village under the Ghosi police station area in Jehanabad district late on Saturday night, leading to tension between two groups of people on Sunday.

Jehanabad SP Manish said a police team led by deputy superintendent of police Ashok Kumar Pandey has been deployed at the village to avoid any untoward incident. A case under Section 302 (murder) has been lodged against the owner of the house and a few others on the statement of the deceased‚Äôs kin.

The incident took place around 11pm on Saturday when Lalbabu allegedly barged into the house of Sudama Kewat at the village. Sudama along with others brutally assaulted the youth on the suspicion of being a thief, causing grievous injuries to him.

Police rushed to the village and rescued the victim from the mob fury. He was admitted to the primary health centre at Ghosi from where he was later referred to the sadar hospital at Jehanabad, where he succumbed to his injuries on Sunday.

SHO of Ghosi police station Dheeraj Kumar said the victim‚Äôs father, Kaushalendra Prasad, told police that his son was mentally challenged. ‚ÄúYet, Kewat and his associates held him captive and thrashed him,‚Äù the SHO quoted the Kaushalendra as saying.

The SHO said Lalu was earlier sent to jail in a theft case lodged with the Kako police station in the district. ‚ÄúTwo separate FIRs have been lodged in connection with the incident. While the first FIR is related to attempted theft in the house of Kewat, the second FIR deals with brutal assault on the youth, leading to his death,‚Äù he added.

The SP said it was being ascertained whether the deceased was undergoing treatment for his ailment or not. ‚ÄúI have asked the SHO to probe the case from all angles,‚Äù he added.

Title: MU to introduce PG course in IT: VC
Content:
GAYA: Magadh University Bodh Gaya will soon introduce postgraduate course in information technology (IT). According to VC Prof Rajendra Prasad, the course will be introduced from the academic session 2020-21 itself. The two years masters course, under the choice-based credit system will have four semesters. ‚ÄúTo begin with, the annual intake has been fixed at 60,‚Äù said the VC.

Asked whether the course will be also introduced in colleges imparting PG education, the VC said teaching in information technology will be conducted only at the headquarters-based PG centre. Before any expansionary move, it is essential to have quality education at one centre in the field of IT. ‚ÄúThe course will go a long way in improving the university‚Äôs academic profile,‚Äù said Prof Rajendra Prasad.

Asked about the proposed course in defence studies, the VC said the Raj Bhavan is yet to give the go ahead signal. Without the Raj Bhavan‚Äôs approval, the new course cannot be introduced. The Chancellor‚Äôs office earlier cleared the proposal for introduction of PG teaching in information technology.

Regarding conducting of pending university exams, the VC said, ‚ÄúA decision will be taken at the end of the ongoing lockdown. The lockdown is scheduled to end on July 31. The university office remains closed during the lockdown period and the employees have been directed to remain present at the headquarters for short notice summons.‚Äù

Earlier, the university had postponed the PG and UG exams scheduled to begin on July 3 and 16 respectively. Asked whether the exams will be held in the conventional pen-paper mode, the VC said that innovative methods of assessment are required to regularise the academic calendar of the university and clear the exam backlog. The academic calendar cannot be easily regularised in the pen-paper mode exam. ‚ÄúMy first priority is to bring the academic calendar back on the rails and clear the exam back log,‚Äù the VC added.

Title: Hyderabad: NGO collects Rs 45 lakh on pretext of treatment, representative booked
